Award.AbstractNarration:
A vision of NSF's biological collections programs is preservation of biological collections in the U.S. and increased accessibility of collections data that will lead to new discoveries through research, and a better understanding and appreciation of biodiversity through improved education and outreach, resulting in improved environmental and economic policies. This workshop seeks to engage the community of herbarium curators and learn from the experiences of other collection types to increase the speed and efficiency of digitization. The activities proposed targets curators and managers across a wide spectrum of institutions distributed across eighteen states.

This award supports participant costs for a workshop for herbarium managers and curators with the goal to consolidate and standardize best practices across the digitization process. The workshop would bring together experts from across the U.S. in sessions hosted by the digitization HUB (iDigBio) and the Southeast Regional Network of Expertise and Collections (SERNEC) to evaluate and publish community-wide standards for all stages of the digitization process. The proposed activities will standardize best practices across the community, increasing the speed and efficiency of digitization resulting in a reduction in the cost of specimen digitization, a major goal of the NSF's biological collections programs (CSBR and ADBC). These efforts will positively impact the quantity and quality of digitized data made available to the research community, government agencies, students, educators, and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Primary biodiversity information derived from museum specimens is essential to our understanding of a wide variety of critical issues such as global change, land-use change and invasive species. In order for this information to be fully accessible, the specimens stored in museums need to be digitized and made freely available in electronic formats on the internet. The National Science Foundation, along with state and private entities, have been investing in this kind of data mobilization in order to benefit a wide variety of stakeholders. A group of museum data mobilization experts met for a product-oriented workshop at Valdosta State University in January 2015. The goal of the workshop was to build a set of best practice documents, creating a resource that would be beneficial for other scientists working in this very active area. Twenty-six scientists from around the country attended the workshop to share their expertise in the areas of specimen image capture, use of imaging equipment, implementation of data standards and data portal access and use. The focus was specifically on imaging and databasing of herbarium specimens (vascular plants, lichens, mosses and fungi). The outcome was a series of workflow documents.  These documents were then crafted into a peer reviewed scientific publication outlining the results and recommendations. The publication itself was deliberately published in an Open Access journal so that anyone with access to the Internet can download it free of charge. The workflow documents were presented as supplementary information and uploaded to the online repository GitHub. By providing open access to these products, we made it easy for anyone to use, share, update or modify the documents for their own specific use and then reload them onto the repository for others to use in the future. These outcomes will provide a valuable resource for the scientific community and will, in time, increase the efficiency by which these data become available to researchers and other state holders who need it most. The overall impact will be to speed the process of specimen image capture and label digitization, as well as quality control/quality assurance capabilities, for large numbers of herbarium collections nationally and globally. This, in turn, will help scientists, students and the public develop a greater understanding and appreciation for our natural history and biodiversity.
